title: Phone Numbers | 1 of 2
question_text:
A statistics teacher collected data on the last digit of her $50$ studentsâ€™ home or cell phone numbers.
She remarked that the results were very similar to choosing $50$ digits from a random digits table. The mean $\mu$ from this distribution was $4.5$, and the standard deviation $\sigma$ was $2.87$.
She then had her students take all possible samples of size $4$ (a daunting task!) from the $50$ pieces of collected data and compute the mean for each sample. They graphed the sample means and calculated the new mean and standard deviation.
What did the graph look like, and what were the values of the new mean and standard deviation?

choices.text:
Shape: discrete uniform
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $2.87$

Shape: discrete uniform
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

Shape: a unimodal and symmetric histogram
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $2.87$

Shape: a unimodal and symmetric histogram
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

Shape: normal curve
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

solution:
The central limit theorem (CLT) tells us that the mean of sample means is the population mean, so the new mean is the same as the original $\mu$ of $4.5$.

The CLT also states that the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of means is obtained by dividing the population standard deviation by the square root of the sample size:

$$\text{Standard deviation}=\dfrac{\text{Population Standard Deviation}}{\sqrt{\text{sample size}}}$$

Thus, the new standard deviation is $\dfrac{\sigma}{\sqrt{ 4}} = \dfrac{\sigma}{2} = \dfrac{2.87}{2} = 1.44$.

The shape of the new distribution will be a histogram that is unimodal and symmetric since the sample means will tend to cluster near the mean $\mu$.

While the new shape is approximately normal, it is technically still a histogram. If the population size were larger, and more samples of size n were taken, the resulting histogram would be essentially a smooth normal curve.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
